Description.val:
DIVING AND SALVAGE EQUIPMENT:
The equipment procured from this Diving and Salvage OPN line item provides critical diving and salvage equipment that enables planned/emergent waterborne submarine/ship repairs, salvage and battle damage repair operations, search and recovery to water depths up to 20,000 feet of seawater and Undersea Clandestine Insertion of Special Operations Forces (UCI-SOF) (service common equipment) to keep our Navy fleet operational and enable national priority missions.   Program objectives are to: (1) provide increased safety for diver decompression and better recompression chamber patient monitoring capability, (2) increase underwater ship maintenance capabilities, (3) improve quick response capability, and (4) standardize the configuration of diving systems in the Fleet.

FY-21 investment in diving capability continues to emphasize phased replacement of aging life support equipment including surface-supplied diving helmets (4), a portable dive control system (1), composite air storage flasks (50), SCUBA regulators (189), and surface supplied augmented SCUBA sets (2).  Navy dive computers (72), required by each diver to calculate decompression penalties, will also be procured.  This equipment is essential to maintaining diving readiness throughout the Fleet.  Additionally we will make investments in new technology equipment that offer capability gains such as Flex recompression chambers (2), which are lighter weight and more easily transported in support of expeditionary diving operations, and equipment, which will significantly improve divers' visual acuity in dark, limited visibility operations.  This improved visual acuity equipment includes sector scan SONAR (3), augmented visual displays (3), 3D SONAR (2) and associated computer based training hardware (1).  When integrated together these systems will produce a virtual environment in which a diver can operate and be directed by topside supervisors to execute salvage, search and recovery and other missions.  Lastly, we continue to invest in upgrades to the Navy Experimental Diving Unit, which houses national assets such as the Ocean Simulation Facility (OSF).  The OSF is a 40+ year old system that permits advanced research and testing of diving technology, diving procedures, human performance, decompression and physiology essential to advancing diving capabilities.

FY-21 investment in Naval Special Warfare Service-Common Equipment continues with acquisition of SCUBA and SONAR equipment kits (16).  

FY-21 investment in Mobile Diving Salvage Unit Outfitting Equipment includes diver launch and recovery system (1), augmented visual displays (3), sector scan SONAR (3), 3D SONAR (1) and SCUBA regulators (8).


FY-21 investment in Salvage and Underwater Ship Husbandry include a commercial off-the-shelf 6,000 meter capable ROV (Remotely Operated Vehicle) (1) for recovery of aircraft and weapons lost in the deep ocean.  This ROV will offer significantly more horsepower than our existing vehicle, which is over 20 years old and in need of replacement.  It represents a one-of-one deep ocean salvage capability for the Navy and DoD.  Other salvage equipment investments include upgrades to existing Clyde Winches (2) used for ship salvage and a 3D imaging SONAR (1) used to map debris fields and provide significant information for mission planning.  In Underwater Ship Husbandry we continue investments in replacing 30 year old 50 ton underwater chain hoists (3) used for a variety of rigging applications.  These hoists are required to replace propellers underwater on aircraft carriers and large deck amphibious ships.  Also required for continuing underwater Ship Husbandry operations, we will acquire underwater hydraulic power tool kits (1), and a pier side support van (1) which houses standard tools and equipment to support underwater operations around the world.  Underwater Ship Husbandry investments continue to produce significant return on investment by eliminating the need for emergent dry-dockings, thereby returning ships to service faster and less expensive than traditional shipyard availabilities.  In FY-18, similar investments eliminated the need for 65 dry-dockings and returned over 700 operating days to the Fleet Commanders.

[P40A / DIVING (N97)]: The DIVING EQUIPMENT to be procured in FY21 in the amount of $3.290M includes modernization of the Navy Experimental Diving Unit's Ocean Simulation Facility, surface supplied diving helmets, surface supplied diving life support consoles and associated air storage flasks, SCUBA equipment, dive computers (wrist mounted for calculating decompression requirements), flexible recompression chambers and Diver Augmented Visual Display (DAVD) equipment.  DAVD investment will provide Navy divers the ability to see and navigate in zero visibility water.  More detailed descriptions are provided below:

[P40A / HY179 - NAVY EXPERIMENTAL DIVING UNIT]: (FY21 = $652,000)  NEDU's mission is to support the Fleet diver through test and evaluation of diving equipment and procedures as well as hyperbaric systems for NAVSEA, Navy, and DoD activities. Funding is to procure equipment for test, facilities atmospheric control, life support, and physiological systems. These systems not only ensure the safety and lives of NEDU sailors performing experimental dives, but ultimately support the combat readiness and mission success of the Fleet sailors who use the equipment tested at NEDU. Funding is included to support the periodic upgrade of Ocean Simulation Facility (OSF) components. The OSF is the world's largest man-rated hyperbaric chamber affording space for 12 divers in 5 hyperbaric dry chambers, man-rated for dives to 2,250 feet of sea water (1000 psi) with a 50' x 15', 55,000-gallon wet-pot capacity, temperatures from 28 to 104 degrees Fahrenheit, an associated 1.3 million-cubic foot (37 km3) bottle field and uses a fully computerized data instrumentation and collection system. Unit prices vary depending on the specific equipment mix planned for upgrade in any single year.

[P40A / HY193 - SURFACE SUPPLIED DIVING HELMET]: (FY21 = 4 @ $7,050 each)  Kirby Morgan KM-37 NS Underwater Breathing Apparatus.  This is a diving helmet with a fiberglass shell and second stage regulator that works in conjunction with a surface supply control console assembly (CCA) and an umbilical. Required I/O is 250.

[P40A / HY199 - NAVY DIVE COMPUTER]: (FY21 = 72 @ $1,587 each)  The Navy Dive Computer is a diver worn decompression computer which provides primarily Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus (SCUBA) divers with real time calculation of decompression limits/obligations. I/O is 1400.

[P40A / HY212 - PORTABLE DIVE SYSTEM CONTROL CONSOLE ASSEMBLY (CCA)]: (FY21 = 1 @ $114,090)  This is a surface supplied diving system control console assembly that will regulate and supply diving breathing gas from the surface to 3 divers. The system is not anticipated to have a volume tank as it will operate on separate high pressure breathing gas sources only. Required Inventory Objective I/O is 100.

[P40A / HY213 - HP COMPOSITE FLASK REPLACEMENT]: (FY21 = 50 @ $5,030 each)  The flasks used in the CAOS, ASRA, OSRA, HOSRA, CASRA, and COSRA all require replacement after 15 years. NAVSEA 00C has will provide the cylinders to fleet diving commands. Required Inventory Objective I/O is 2500.

[P40A / HY224 - SCUBA REGULATORS]: (FY21 = 189 @ $1,060 each)  This is 1st and 2nd stage Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus (SCUBA) regulator fitted with an additional octopus 2nd stage and a console with both a cylinder pressure gauge and diver's depth gauge included. I/O is 5,000.

[P40A / HY226 - FLEX CHAMBER]: (FY21 = 2 @ $548,390 each)  The flexible recompression chamber system is composed of a double-lock flexible chamber, control console, gas supply and interconnecting hoses.  The flex chamber is designed as an extreme lightweight system used to treat diver's injuries, including Arterial Gas Embolism and Decompression Sickness.  I/O is 36.

[P40A / HY233 - SURFACE SUPPLY AUGMENTED SCUBA SYSTEM]: (FY21 = 2 @ $108,680 each)  The Surface Supply Augmented SCUBA System consists of the Interspiro DIVIATOR Dive Panel (DP) Surface Supply System and the Interspiro DIVIATOR Self Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus (SCUBA) System. This is a lightweight, highly portable system which makes is ideal for rapid deployment to remote locations.  The apparatus combines the capability of surface supplied diving with the portability of SCUBA.  Required Inventory Objective I/O is 50.

[P40A / HY234 - DIVER AUGMENTED VISUAL DISPLAY (DAVD)]: (FY21 = 3 @ 39,970 each)  The Diver Augmented Visual Display (DAVD) is a system that incorporates 3D sonar mapping, high speed - high frequency helmet mounted sonar, diver tracking, and a head's up display into an existing USN underwater breathing apparatus (UBA).  The system allows a diver in low/no visibility waters to locate targets of interest, transit to the location and see their work environment in real-time.  In addition, the system allows a top-side diving supervisor to monitor the divers work progress.  Each system includes equipment for one diver.  Required Inventory Objective I/O is 173

[P40A / HY250 - DAVD SECTOR SCAN SONAR]: (FY21 = 3 @ 46,970 each)  The sector scan sonar is a 2D portable sonar system that mounts on a tripod that is lowered to the bottom that provides 360-degree continuous sonar imagery to the DAVD topside control box. The system has a useable range of 300 meters out from the sonar head. This system has been evaluated for electrical and acoustic safety and is approved for use with US Navy Divers.  I/O = 50

[P40A / HY251 - DAVD 3D SONAR]: (FY21 = 2 @ $101,580)  The 3D sonar imaging system produces real time high-resolution 3D imagery that can be used to create a 3D model of a large undersea area. The system is also capable of producing real time sonar imagery that can be over-laid onto a previously produced 3D model and used for diver locating and navigation controlled by the DAVD topside control system. The CODA is capable of tracking the diver working on the bottom and has a range of over 300 meters. This system has been evaluated for electrical and acoustic safety and is approved for use with US Navy Divers. HY-251 and HY-254 -  This equipment significantly improve divers visual acuity in dark, limited visibility operations.  This improved visual acuity equipment includes sector scan SONAR (3), augmented visual displays (3), 3D SONAR (1) and associated computer based training hardware (1).  When integrated together these systems will produce a virtual environment in which a diver can operate and be directed by topside supervisors to execute salvage, search and recovery and other missions.   I/O = 50

[P40A / HY254 - DAVD COMPUTER BASED TRAINING SYSTEMS]: (FY21 = 1 @ 152,370)  Computer based training system that will provide training to USN divers in the operation and maintenance of the DAVD system. HY-251 and HY-254:  This equipment significantly improve divers' visual acuity in dark, limited visibility operations.  This improved visual acuity equipment includes sector scan SONAR (3), augmented visual displays (3), 3D SONAR (1) and associated computer based training hardware (1).  When integrated together these systems will produce a virtual environment in which a diver can operate and be directed by topside supervisors to execute salvage, search and recovery and other missions. I/O = 10

[P40A / NSW SERVICE-COMMON EQUIPMENT (N95)]: The NSW SERVICE COMMON EQUIPMENT to be procured in FY21 in the amount of $1.725M includes SCUBA and hand-held sonar and diver visualization systems.  More detailed descriptions are provided below:

[P40A / HY235 - NSW SERVICE COMMON SCUBA/SONAR KIT]: (FY21 = 16 @ $107,810 each)  This kit includes standard SCUBA gear for one diver including: regulator, buoyancy compensator, mask, fins, gloves, boots, suits.  In addition, it also includes handheld SONAR systems, lights and other diver visualization gear. I/O is 200

[P40A / MOBILE DIVING SALVAGE UNIT (MDSU) OUTFITTING EQUIPMENT (N95)]: The DIVING EQUIPMENT to be procured in FY21 in the amount of $0.683M provides prioritized outfitting for Mobile Diving Salvage Unit (MDSU), Explosive Ordinance Disposal (EOD) Commands and Underwater Construction Team (UCT) Table of Allowance (TOA) requirements of centrally managed diving systems and equipment.  This equipment includes diving, salvage and combat support equipment to meet Required Operational Capabilities / Projected Operational Environment (ROC/POE) and Navy Mission Essential Tasks (NMET) to include underwater visual augmentation systems, dive computers, diver launch and recovery systems, flexible recompression chambers, sonar systems and SCUBA regulators.

[P40A / HY255 - DIVER LARS - NECC]: (FY21=1 @ $312,340) This item replaces and improves upon the capabilities provided by current Diver Launch and Recovery Systems (LARS) utilized by Nay Expeditionary Combat Command (NECC) forces.   This is an A-Frame style LARS wth a stage to deploy divers from the deck of a vessel.

[P40A / HY256 - DAVD GEN 1 - NECC]: (FY21 = 3 @ $39,970) The diver augmented visual display (DAVD) is a system that incorporates 2D/3D sonar mapping, diver tracking and a head's up display (HUD) into an existing USN underwater breathing apparatus (UBA).  The system allows a Navy Expeditionary Combat Command (NECC) diver in low/no visibility waters to locate targets if interest, transit to the location and see their work in real time.  In addition, the system allows a top-side diving supervisor to monitor the divers and their progress.

[P40A / HY257 - DAVD SECTOR SCAN SONAR - NECC]: (FY21 = 3 @ $46,970) The sector scan sonar is a 2D portable sonar system that mounts on a tripod that is lowered to the bottom that provides 360-degree continuous sonar imagery to the Diver Augmented Vistal Display (DAVD) topside control box.  This is intended for use by Navy Expeditionary Combat Command (NECC) divers.

[P40A / HY258 - DAVD 3D SONAR - NECC]: (FY21 = 1 @ $101,580) The 3D sonar imaging system produces real-time, high resolution 3D imagery that can be used to create a 3D model of a large undersea area.  This equipment is intended to work in conjunction with or separate from the Diver Augmented Visual Display (DAVD) systems deployed by Navy Expeditionary Combat Command divers.

[P40A / HY263 - SCUBA REGULATORS - NECC]: (FY21 = 8 @ $1,060) These a self contained underwater breathing apparatus (SCUBA) regulators that are used to reduce air pressure in a SCUBA cylinder and deliver that air at a useable pressure to a Navy Expeditionary Combat Command (NECC) diver.  The make and model of the SCUBA regulator shall be approved on the US Navy Authorized for Navy Use (ANU) list.

[P40A / SALVAGE (N97)]: The SALVAGE EQUIPMENT to be procured in FY21 in the amount of $5.445M includes a work-class Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV), 3D sonar equipment, salvage winch upgrades, underwater power tools.  Also included are underwater ship husbandry equipment (video kit, pierside support systems and 50 ton hydraulic chain hoists) to permit divers to make underwater repairs to ships and submarines afloat. More detailed descriptions are provided below:

[P40A / HY169 - UWSH POWER TOOLS]: (FY21 = 1 @ $102,000)  These tools will replace the hydraulic tool previously issued to Fleet divers with improved technology.  This technology improvement will provide tools which are more environmentally compatible, offer greater power, lighter weight  and reduced maintenance.  I/O is 20.

[P40A / HY197 - UWSH PIERSIDE SUPPORT VANS]: (FY21 = 1 @ $205,000)  Portable milvans and shippable containers outfitted with general and special purpose tools to support various underwater ship husbandry operations.  I/O is 12.

[P40A / HY223 - 3D SONAR]: (FY21 = 1 @ 566,000)  This system generates a 3D Image of the area or object being surveyed and is viewable in real time.  The record of data is viewable off line for mission planning, allows for the measurement of distances and dimensions, and can be used during mission execution for operational control and situational awareness in zero visibility situations.  I/O is 2.

[P40A / HY228 - CLYDE WINCH UPGRADE MODIFICATIONS]: (FY21 = 2 @ $108,500 each)  Portable Clyde deck winch consists of a dual drum assembly and a horizontal capstan mounted on the side of the deck winch.  The deck winch is hydraulically driven by  a self contained diesel engine and each drum/ capstan can pull up to 8 tons.  The drive mechanism and braking system is upgraded to a hydraulic control and operation.    Required I/O is 20.

[P40A / HY243 -  WORK CLASS ROV]: (FY21 = 1 @ 3,980,000)  Industrial capacity ROV capable of +100HP work and rated in depth to at least 6000 meters.  Required I/O is 1. Current ROV system is a 'one-off' system approaching end-of-life and becoming increasing difficult to support which threatens on-call capability. This capability is specifically required by Navy Salvage Requirement and Policy (OPNAVINST 4740.2G) which directs a deep ocean search and recovery capability down to 20,000 feet. Such ROVs are now available in the commercial sector and are dependably supportable world-wide, using available components that are of current technology.

[P40A / HY248 -  HYDRAULIC CHAIN HOIST (50 TON)]: (FY21 = 3 @ $125,000 each)  This system provides a means to lift loads utilizing rigging points under water.  These Hydraulic Chain Hoists are specially designed for underwater use and are sized to safely lift 50 tons.  Required I/O is 15.

Name.val: 1.6) HY210 - COMPACT DIVER LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEM AIR SUPPLY
1.7) HY212 - PORTABLE DIVE SYSTEM CONTROL CONSOLE ASSEMBLY (CCA)

Name.@footnote: HY226 FLEX CHAMBER introduces lightweight fabric recompression chambers to replace some aging steel chambers.  Flex chambers reduce size and weight of steel chambers and are ideally suited for expeditionary diving forces.  The fabric used on the chambers is the result of several years of development and testing.

Name.val: 1.11) HY233 - SURFACE SUPPLY AUGMENTED SCUBA SYSTEM

Name.@footnote: HY251 - DAVD 3D SONAR - These sonars provide a three-dimensional rendering of the underwater environment.  This allows for the creation of a real time augmented reality for divers working in dark or occluded waters (i.e. 'allows them to see in the dark').  This is one capability set for the Divers Augmented Visual Display.  These sonars can also be used on their own to find underwater wreckage, targets of interest or obstructions that could pose a danger to divers.

HY254 - DAVD COMPUTER BASED TRAINING SYSTEMS - This is a computer based training (CBT) system that will provide training for personnel who need to dive with or act as surface operator of a Diver Augmented Visual Display (DAVD) system.  These CBT systems will be strategically located at diver concentration areas so that they are easily accessed by the most possible divers.  Without these systems it will be necessary to incorporate this training into Dive School at the Naval Diving and Salvage Training Center (NDSTC) or provide a Tiger Team type training on a rotating basis.  Both of those other options are determined to cost more money with no added knowledge gain.
Name.val: 1.18) HY254 - DAVD COMPUTER BASED TRAINING SYSTEMS

Name.@footnote: HY235 - NSW SERVICE COMMON SCUBA/SONAR KIT - These kits provide life support and covert navigation capability to US Navy SEALs.  The systems allow for long range underwater navigation for an individual or team to conduct an insertion from a large US Navy asset to shore.  Loss of any of this funding will result in a degraded Special Forces Capability.
Name.val: 2.1) HY235 - NSW SERVICE COMMON SCUBA/SONAR KIT
2.2) HY236 - NSW SERVICE COMMON STANDARD DOUBLE LOCK RECOMPRESSION CHAMBER
3) MOBILE DIVING SALVAGE UNIT (MDSU) OUTFITTING EQUIPMENT (N95)
3.3) HY257 - DAVD SECTOR SCAN SONAR - NECC
4.16) HY198 - UWSH SURFACE SHIP SUPPORT SYSTEMS
4.21) HY206 - KERRIE CABLE UNDERWATER CUTTING SYSTEM
4.25) HY227 - COMPLEX AND/OR LARGE UWSH REPAIR COFFERDAM SUPPORT SYSTEMS
4.27) HY229 - AC SOLAR CELL DEPLOYMENT KIT
4.28) HY230 - NEXGEN HYDRAULIC POWER UNIT, MOD 6B
4.30) HY232 - DECK SYSTEMS HYDRAULIC POWER UNIT UPGRADE
4.34) HY240 - SALVAGE PATCHING AND RIGGING VAN

Name.@footnote: HY243 -  WORK CLASS ROV - A commercial off-the-shelf 6,000 meter capable ROV (Remotely Operated Vehicle) (1) for recovery of aircraft and weapons lost in the deep ocean.  This ROV will offer significantly more horsepower than our existing vehicle, which is over 20 years old and in need of replacement.  It represents a one-of-one deep ocean salvage capability for the Navy and DoD. This 6,000 meter remote recovery capability serves both unclassified and more importantly, classified high tempo recoveries.  The capability is considered a 'National Asset' and has peer competitor implications.
